bibl.title: Despatches from United States Consuls in Gaboon, 1856-1888 T-466

text.body:
Dear Sir,
My Exequaature together with the Circular So 47. has been recieved. During an interview with the Commander in Chief of the French squadum upon the West Coast of Africa, he informed me that . There *clay fith steamer has recently left Clapgton* in Servland*. Some recieved circumstances in urgent to the vessels lead. the Authorities in England to notify he English and French Admirats here to been the boats on for them. One of them has been upon the coach an succeded in Making its escape with seven hundred miquro though merchant by thirteen steamers of the English Signture. Stablized at upon arrivals with boats beteen the vessels. This was in the *memity of Bydah in the Bight if Bonin. I have no information of the others. The Admiral expressed fear that these vessels are succed in securing they would the Rebel flag.
and prey upon American COmmerce By the time i recieve on one to this. I shall have been at my previous duty but again, which of sapphere is as long as any gold can remain in this chate upon three first re- >unclear< to be informed if it will be necessary for me to appoint a tier Comml. Agt. I have the honor to be your most obedient Servant Henry May U.S. Comml. Agt.
